channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-7379] Port '[89-fb] prevent OOM possibility due to per connection responseQueue being unbounded' to trunk
item.description:
HBASE-6728 ported '[89-fb] prevent OOM possibility due to per connection responseQueue being unbounded' to 0.94 branch

This issue is to port it to trunk
item.summary: Port '[89-fb] prevent OOM possibility due to per connection responseQueue being unbounded' to trunk

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Patch rebased on trunk.
Response queue size uses metrics2 framework.

TestSizeBasedThrottler passes.

The RPC metrics already have the rpc queue length and rpc queue size metrics. https://github.com/apache/hbase/blob/trunk/hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/ipc/MetricsHBaseServerWrapperImpl.java

It doesn't seem like duplicating those is necessary.

Thanks for the timely review, Elliott.

The new metric is for response queue size which is not covered by the metrics in MetricsHBaseServerWrapperImpl.

Please correct me if I am wrong.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12561422/7379-trunk.txt
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 6 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

-1 findbugs. The patch appears to introduce 26 new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 core tests. The patch passed unit tests in .

-1 core zombie tests. There are zombie tests. See build logs for details.

Elliott Clark: Can you take a look at patch v2 ?

stack:
Do you have comments about patch v2 ?

Thanks

• MetricsRegionServerWrapperStub.java has an un-needed change.
  • There are lots of import changes that seem to just be re-orderings.
  • The API of the throttler is pretty weird. Why aren't we sub-classing BlockingQueue and making poll/enqueue do all of the work in there ? Right now it just seems weird that all accesses of the list need to be paired with an access to responseQueuesSizeThrottler
  • It looks like a connection could be starved. If it wants to put in a large amount of data and there are lots of connections that are putting in small amounts of data then it's possible this connection will lose the race to the lock and never get to respond. Seems like there needs to be some queueing mechanism for who gets notified when we are below the high water mark again.
  • This will be less useful as the new methods of sending responses come that don't make any copies.

Thanks for the review, Elliott.

Looking at BlockingQueue API, I wonder how we handle point #4 (starvation) above.
Suppose requests r1, r2 and r3 are in the queue where r1 carries data much larger than those of r2 and r3. When we take r1 off the queue and discover that its data size exceeds threshold, do we put it at the end of the queue or put r1 at the head of the queue (after tacking out r2) ?
Would we face similar situation where r1 is continuously pushed off ?

This will be less useful as the new methods of sending responses come that don't make any copies.

Elliott Clark Can you remind me in which JIRA issue the above would be done ?

HBASE-7233 has most of the thoughts. but the general gist, as it related to this jira, is that if things are streamed across not using protobuf for anything but RpcHeader then we won't have any copies in the rpc response layer.

Thanks for the reminder - discussion on that JIRA was very long.

I don't know when the solution for HBASE-7233 would come up. Elliott Clark Do you think this patch can go in first ?

As it is I'm -1 on the patch.

  • The api seems bad.
  • It can starve out some calls from ever being sent.
  • The RPC stuff will go in before 0.96 is released so I don't think that copying and memory usage in the rpc response layer will be a big deal going forward. (If it looks like this isn't true then re-writing the patch would be an option.)

I have some idea about addressing starvation problem by using PriorityQueue where we place an upper bound on the duration an item can stay.
According to description above, related work in RPC should address OOME issue. So I will wait a little bit to see if this JIRA is needed for 0.96
Moving out task that needs finishing. We can pull it back if done before 0.96.
Downgrade to minor considering https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-7379?focusedCommentId=13538419&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-13538419
Looks like this is no longer needed.
Resolving as 'wont fix' per Ted comment above that it is no longer needed.
